children.subject: any suggestions for how to do that?
Bro you've taken almost all there is. Go to the outside world and get some hands-on experience.

history.content:
If you take EE120, 223 and 226A are excellent follow-up classes for 126. There's also 227BT, a follow-up to 127.

As for 189, I think 182 builds on it?

I think 104 would also be a good experience just to build mathematical maturity.

You're at one of the best EECS universities in the world. I'm pretty sure you'll never run out of things to learn here ;).

children.subject: Totally agree, real analysis is a must for theoretical statistical learning and the concepts in analysis are seen everywhere in mathematical statistics. Having taken Math 104 and 202A, I can say that 202A definitely covers measure theory in enough detail, but I'm not sure 105 does.

For Stat 210A, in my opinion Math 104 is almost a prerequisite (I think Professor Fithian requires it to enroll in the class). In the last few weeks of the semester when MLE is covered, the proofs get very technical, and a good understanding of analysis is incredibly helpful. 

However the real question is, what do you want to do with statistics/ML in the future. If you want to go to industry, you are pretty much set for most non-research positions; just do some personal projects and you should be good. If you want to focus on social science applications, look for professors that do research in the applied areas you are interested in, and ask if they need statistical/data science help, which you can provide. 

If you want to go to grad school, specifically in statistics, analysis is almost a prerequisite for getting in anywhere. As an example, Berkeley Stats PhDs usually take Stat 205 and 210 their first year, and lack of previous exposure to measure theory (introduced in Math 105/202A) usually results in 205 being a very painful experience.

history.content:
Not sure how to advance my stats/data science/etc education w.r.t. coursework. Data 8/Stat 140/CS C100 all seem too easy after taking (and doing pretty well) in the above three classes. Stat 133 and 134 also seem too basic.

What are your thoughts on Stat 135, 151A, 159 (?) or potentially 210A (would I be ready without real analysis)? Other classes? Or are there better ways to advance my education in this space outside of coursework? I am specifically interested in applications in social science research, so applied stuff would be cool too (although I'd appreciate the theoretical background first).

Thanks :)
history.subject: How to advance stats/dats science education after finishing CS 189, EE126 and 127?
